Explanation: \texttt{N} is an integer (int) and cannot be lower than 1
\texttt{y} contains \texttt{N} integers and \texttt{y} is an array (arrays are different from vectors and matrices, which are limited to one and two dimensions, respectively)
\texttt{id} contains \texttt{N} integers that must be between 1 and \texttt{J} (where \texttt{J} is also an integer)
produces a sequence of integers between 1 and \texttt{K}-1 (e.g., if \texttt{K} is 6 the result would be \texttt{[1,2,3,4,5]})
\texttt{X} is a matrix with \texttt{N} rows and 2 columns
\texttt{b\_d} is an array of \texttt{J} numbers that can take any value
\texttt{tau\_d} is a single number that can take any value of 0 or greater

produce a sequence of integers between 1 and \texttt{N} and for each integer (\texttt{i}) in this sequence run the code between the braces (note \texttt{i} is often used by convention but doesn’t have to be)
\texttt{x} is assumed to be normally distributed with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
the element of \texttt{b} in position \texttt{i} is equal to the dot product of row \texttt{i} of matrix \texttt{X} and \texttt{B\_d}
find the \texttt{id} of the participant that observation \texttt{i} comes from (\texttt{id[i]}) and use this to select the value of \texttt{b\_b} corresponding to that \texttt{id}
element \texttt{i} of \texttt{y} is sampled from a categorical distribution with probabilities determined by element \texttt{i} of \texttt{theta}

if \texttt{k} and \texttt{K} are integers the result of \texttt{k\/K} will also be an integer, which is not what we want when setting the unbiased criteria of the SDT model. Subtracting the logarithms and taking the exponent produces the non-integer result we desire
